item.content:encoded:
[tatsu_section bg_color= "#151515" bg_repeat= "no-repeat" bg_attachment= "scroll" bg_position= "center center" bg_stretch= "1" bg_animation= "none" border_color= "" bg_video_mp4_src= "" bg_video_ogg_src= "" bg_video_webm_src= "" overlay_color= "" section_id= "" full_screen_header_scheme= "background--dark" padding= "125px 0% 0px 0%" bg_size= "cover" border= "0px 0px px 0px"][tatsu_row layout= "1/1"][tatsu_column layout= "1/1"][tatsu_text max_width= "60" wrap_alignment= "left" animation_type= "fadeIn"]

item.excerpt:encoded: Detracto erroribus et mea. Malorum temporibus vix ex. Ius ad iudico labores dissentiunt.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ghbybgbybh

Based on a rough, back of the envelope computation, the quantity of carbon dioxide that would need to be removed is roughly what would be produced by about 60 gigawatts of coal fired electrical power geanantioe.Plerse correct me if I am wrong. Nuclear fission is certainly capable of this scale of development, but if the inventor has to actually put the plan into production before getting the prize, $25 million is a tiny drop in the bucket in the implementation cost.Of course I know that the nuclear plants will also produce income; my point is that the offer may be just a good PR ploy.
In the cotlpicamed world we live in, it's good to find simple solutions.
